Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Optical tweezers won the 2018 Nobel Prize in physics for their applications in biological systems. The tweezers use a highly focused laser beam to trap and manipulate small objects, including cells, particles, bacteria, and virus. Despite the huge success of optical tweezers, the requirement of sophisticated optical setups and high working power prevent their non-invasive manipulation of fragile objects. Tremendous efforts have been made to develop new techniques for optical trapping. However, a universal strategy to safely manipulate different particles and cells in various liquid environments is still elusive. This proposal aims to develop a new optical tweezing platform based on laser cooling and thermal migration of particles in a temperature gradient. Laser cooling can create a localized cold spot on a substrate where various particles can be trapped by thermophoresis. The cooling-induced trapping is expected to effectively avoid the thermal damages due to optical heating in conventional optical tweezer, and the general thermophoretic migration behavior allows this strategy to be used for a wide range of biological cells and nanoparticles to advance life sciences and biomedical applications, including tissue engineering, cellular biology, early disease diagnosis, and drug delivery. The proposed research at the interfaces of physics, photonics, thermo-fluidics, colloidal sciences, and biology will provide interdisciplinary research opportunities for graduate students, undergraduate students, and K-12 students. The outreach efforts will be integrated into two existing Women in Engineering Program initiatives on campus to increase recruiting women and underrepresented minorities into engineering.

Opto-thermophoretic tweezers were recently developed as an alternative strategy to manipulate particles and cells in a light-controlled temperature gradient with simple optics and low operation power. However, the current laser-heating-based opto-thermophoretic tweezers suffer from limited applicability to special solvent conditions and potential optothermal damages. The objective of this proposal is to develop and apply new opto-thermophoretic tweezers based on laser cooling of the substrates. Due to the common thermophobia in colloidal species, a variety of biological cells and particles can be trapped at the laser beams via thermophoresis in their native environments. In addition, this design can avoid thermal damages due to the temperature increase in optical tweezers and the heating-based opto-thermophoretic tweezers. The proposed research will provide a novel platform for versatile and non-invasive optical manipulation for nanoparticles and biological cells. The intellectual merit is that the proposed research will improve fundamental understanding of laser cooling and thermophoresis, establish safe optical manipulation techniques for cells in biological media, and advance biological applications of optical tweezers, including studies of cell-cell interactions and thermal cues in cellular behaviors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Within 2020, the Zheng Group was awarded an NSF Grant entitled “Laser-Cooling-Driven Opto-Thermophoretic Tweezers”, with the acronym for the title being “LCOTTs”. Traditional Optical Tweezers exert high laser power and require refractive index contrast, which in turn results in in both thermal and photon damage to trapped objects such as biological cells and other nanoparticles. Advanced tweezers such as optothermal tweezers, though requiring less laser power than Traditional Optical Tweezers, are still limited by the medium which is employed and intense laser heating effects. It is for this reason as to why the project regarding LCOTTs was launched in an effort to enhance precision, versatility, and biocompatibility of manipulation, ultimately improving the Laser Manipulation Field as a whole. Key goals of this project include to investigate the multiphase flow and transport of colloidal particles in the laser cooling generated temperature gradient, to physically develop LCOTTs and measure the thermophoretic trapping of colloidal particles, and to demonstrate the versatile trapping and dynamic manipulation of cells with LCOTTs in biological media.

Between 2020 and 2023, significant progress was made toward these objectives through a systematic exploration of heat-mediated optical manipulation techniques. During 2020-2021, foundational work focused on establishing the principles of optothermal manipulation, including the development of laser-cooling-driven optothermal tweezers through the use of Ytterbium-doped Yttrium Lithium Fluoride substrates and other multimodal manipulation methods capable of out-of-plane rotation. In 2021-2022, the research expanded to demonstrate the usage of optothermoelectric tweezers through designing a new system composed of polyethylene glycol (PEG) and phosphate buffered saline (PBS) solution along with functionalized substrates, which enabling the synergy of light-induced depletion force, thermoelectric force and electrokinetic force, along with a multi-modal manipulation of nano-and micro-particles to help tweeze and roll yeast cells in a safe manner. By 2022-2023, the project achieved breakthroughs in three-dimensional manipulation of plasmonic vesicles, demonstrating controlled cargo release for potential drug delivery applications through the usage of Hypothermal Opto-Thermophoretic Tweezers (HOTTs), which enabled even less thermal damage and power usage for the laser through manipulating the environment’s temperature and reversing a thermophoretic force to be attractive. Additionally, a multimodal manipulation system was developed for use along rough biological surfaces, overcoming the limitations of light-responsive substrates. The team also introduced a single-cell rotation-based method for subcellular binding kinetics characterization, providing label-free, high-resolution quantification of cell adhesion dynamics. These achievements highlighted the potential of optothermal techniques for a wide range of biomedical and biophysical applications.

In 2023-2024, the project focused on groundbreaking developments in several complex areas of study. One notable achievement was the study of thermophoretic behaviors in heat-dissociative coacervate droplets, uncovering how temperature gradients drive molecular redistribution and interfacial tension variations, providing insights into prebiotic molecular organization. Adaptive algorithms were also developed to enhance the responsiveness and stability of LCOTT-based laser manipulated microrobotic swarms, enabling efficient navigation in complex environments through real-time feedback control. These principles were successfully applied to an elliptical-approximation algorithm to achieve long-distance autonomous navigation of microrobotic swarms via LCOTT-based laser manipulation, demonstrating obstacle avoidance and adaptive control in constrained settings. Furthermore, the optothermal manipulation platform was extended to multicellular organisms, specifically C. elegans. By integrating a cooling apparatus with laser-generated microbubbles, the team achieved biocompatible manipulation of nematodes through a combination of the Marangoni convection flow and the surface tension of the bubble, demonstrating the system's potential for omnidirectional dynamic chemotaxis assays and broader biological research applications while ensuring minimal damage to the worm. This work therefore represents a significant leap forward in both the technical capabilities and practical applications of optothermal manipulation, building fundamental discoveries such as the building of the laser cooling system to implementing LCOTTs and it’s subsequent principles to help microrobots navigate complex systems or manipulating a complex multicellular organism such as C. elegans, leading the Zheng Group to be truly thankful for being granted this grant.


Last Modified: 12/31/2024
Modified by: Yuebing Zheng
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Within 2020, the Zheng Group was awarded an NSF Grant entitled Laser-Cooling-Driven Opto-Thermophoretic Tweezers, with the acronym for the title being LCOTTs. Traditional Optical Tweezers exert high laser power and require refractive index contrast, which in turn results in in both thermal and photon damage to trapped objects such as biological cells and other nanoparticles. Advanced tweezers such as optothermal tweezers, though requiring less laser power than Traditional Optical Tweezers, are still limited by the medium which is employed and intense laser heating effects. It is for this reason as to why the project regarding LCOTTs was launched in an effort to enhance precision, versatility, and biocompatibility of manipulation, ultimately improving the Laser Manipulation Field as a whole. Key goals of this project include to investigate the multiphase flow and transport of colloidal particles in the laser cooling generated temperature gradient, to physically develop LCOTTs and measure the thermophoretic trapping of colloidal particles, and to demonstrate the versatile trapping and dynamic manipulation of cells with LCOTTs in biological media. During 2020-2021, foundational work focused on establishing the principles of optothermal manipulation, including the development of laser-cooling-driven optothermal tweezers through the use of Ytterbium-doped Yttrium Lithium Fluoride substrates and other multimodal manipulation methods capable of out-of-plane rotation. Additionally, a multimodal manipulation system was developed for use along rough biological surfaces, overcoming the limitations of light-responsive substrates. The team also introduced a single-cell rotation-based method for subcellular binding kinetics characterization, providing label-free, high-resolution quantification of cell adhesion dynamics. In 2023-2024, the project focused on groundbreaking developments in several complex areas of study. This work therefore represents a significant leap forward in both the technical capabilities and practical applications of optothermal manipulation, building fundamental discoveries such as the building of the laser cooling system to implementing LCOTTs and its subsequent principles to help microrobots navigate complex systems or manipulating a complex multicellular organism such as C. elegans, leading the Zheng Group to be truly thankful for being granted this grant.
